paragraphs.text: The hostage rescue dilemma.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: Saturday's failed hostage rescue mission in Yemen was indeed tragic
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: While the official details as to exactly what happened have not yet been released
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: it appears Luke Somers, an American journalist, and Pierre Korkie, a South African teacher, were killed by their captors during a night-time rescue attempt carried out by US Navy SEALs
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) had been holding Somers and Korkie captive for over a year
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: It was the second such attempt to rescue Somers in two weeks
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: On November 25, a SEALs team hit what they thought was the compound holding Somers
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: who, as it turns out, had been moved from there just hours before
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: In Saturday's operation, the SEALs knew Somers' exact location
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: To maintain stealth, they landed by V-22 Osprey several kilometres away, and then made the trek overland to the compound where Somers and Korkie were being held captive
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: But something went terribly wrong in the final approach
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Perhaps it was a barking dog or some other noise
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the SEALs came under fire as they approached the compound's main entrance
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The element of surprise, which is so critical to rescue operations, was lost
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: a fierce firefight ensued
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Within 30 minutes, the SEALs had secured the compound and put Somers and Korkie, who were both still alive on a V-22 that had a surgical team standing by
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Unfortunately, medics were unable to save them
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Plainly necessary
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: For Somers, Saturday's rescue mission was as urgent as it was plainly necessary
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Late last week AQAP released a video stating he would be killed in 72 hours unless unspecified demands were met
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Those demands have not been made public, but likely involved payment of a ransom or release of AQAP captives, something the US is prohibited by law from doing
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: For Korkie, the sense of urgency in attempting the rescue operation is more controversial
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: According to the South African charity Gift of the Giving, a deal had been made with AQAP to release Korkie in just a matter of days, suggesting to many that it would have been better to wait
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Maybe there was a deal that would have gone through in the end
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Maybe there wasn't
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But in rescue operations, hope is not figured into the equation
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: where planners and decision makers have to weigh the risks of action against the consequences of inaction
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: By their very nature, hostage rescue operations are among the most difficult and risky military missions to carry out
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: With little margin for error, either in intelligence or the operation itself, they demand highly trained and equipped special operations units that only a handful of countries have
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Are they dangerous and uncertain?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Absolutely
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: Are they impossible?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: No
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: In 2012, US Navy SEALs rescued Jessica Buchanan, an American aid worker, and Poul Hagen Thisted, a Danish aid worker
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: who had been held hostage by Somali pirates for 93 days
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The pirates were demanding a $45m ransom for their release
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: In this particular case, precise intelligence as to their exact location, along with concerns about Buchanan's rapidly declining health, were major factors in moving forward with the rescue mission
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Under the cover of darkness, the SEAL Team parachuted 19km from where they were being held, and then moved cross-country to conduct the rescue
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Nine pirates were killed during the operation
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Buchanan and Thisted were unharmed
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: In 2009, US Navy SEAL snipers ended the hostage ordeal of American Richard Phillips, captain of the cargo ship Maersk Alabama
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: which had been hijacked by Somali pirates in the Indian Ocean five days earlier
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Talks with the pirates ended when they threw the phone used to communicate with negotiators into the ocean
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: When
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: one of the pirates pointed his rifle at Captain Phillips' back
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: snipers shot and killed all three in near simultaneous fashion
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Captain Phillips was unharmed
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Heartbreaking failures
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: In 2005, US Delta Force operators rescued Roy Hallums, an American civilian contractor kidnapped by an al-Qaeda cell in Iraq, after 311 days in captivity
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Again
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the intelligence as to Hallums' location was exact
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: - pull up the kitchen carpet and open the faux cement trap door leading into his one room cell
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Hallums was unharmed in the operation
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: But
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: as was all too evident on Saturday, there are heartbreaking failures, too
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: This past July, US special operations forces attempted to rescue James Foley in Syria
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Unfortunately, the intelligence as to where he was being held was incorrect
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Foley was brutally murdered by ISIL just a few weeks later
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: the videotape of which was released on the internet for the world to see
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: In 2010, the US special operations team attempting to rescue her in Afghanistan accidentally killed Linda Norgrove, a British citizen
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: There are other failures, all tragic, as well
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But there are also other successes
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: where hostages like Jessica Buchanan, Poul Thisted, Captain Phillips and Roy Hallums, all of whom faced indefinite captivity or even death, are home with their families because decisions were made to rescue them based on calculated risks
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: No guessing, no maybes, no "let's keep our fingers crossed and hope for the best"
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Rescue missions are risky, both for the hostages and for the operators who carry them out
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Lives are at stake
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it's never an easy choice to give the "green light"
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: But given the circumstances, particularly when dealing with terrorist organisations, leaders can't always sit back and wait to see what happens
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Sometimes, it's less risky to act than not to
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And in the case of a hostage rescue operation, I'd place my life in the hands of men dedicated to the task before taking my chances with the likes of a terrorist in the hope that maybe they'll let me go
paragraphs.label: assumption
